DEB WALLACE: Welcome to
our second Books@Baker. I'm Deb Wallace, the executive
director of Baker Library.

And I can promise this is-- [INAUDIBLE] this is our
second online session.

And we did a pretty good
job on the first one when Laura Huang joined us to
talk about her book, Edge--

Turning Adversity
into Advantage. So we're very eager
to try this out again

with our dear friend,
Hiro Takeuchi. We certainly miss
the opportunity to welcome you to an
Aldrich classroom,

but actually moving
online has enabled us to open up participation.

Our Global Research
Center staff-- many are joining us. Students are now scattered
around the world.

They can join us. Large number of people who
are regularly not on campus,

and we're delighted that
you're able to join us. So it's been nearly
six weeks since we've

been working remotely, and we've
been staring at this screen.

And I don't know about
you, but frankly, I find it kind of exhausting.

But I promise you that
this next hour is not going to be exhausting at all.

In fact, it's going to be
incredibly invigorating. Before I turn to Hiro to talk
to us about his new book,

just want to walk you
through the program. We're going to take about
20, 25 minutes where

Hiro will talk about his work. And then we'll open
it up for questions. And you can put your
questions in through Chat,

which I will moderate for you. We're going to keep all the
mics muted so that there's not

a lot of extraneous noise. So I'd like to introduce
Professor Hiro Takeuchi.

Given he's so well
known to so many of you, an introduction hardly
seems necessary.

I'd rather spend the majority
of our time talking with him than talking about him.

But it's probably
noteworthy to just mention a few of the things he's
[AUDIO OUT] at HBS, where

he has continued to extend his
seminal research with Professor Nonaka, the two fathers of
the whole field of knowledge

management. He's a member of the strategy
unit, continues to write and teach about
knowledge-based strategies.

He's taking students yearly
to study the crisis management approaches employed after
the devastating earthquake

and tsunami in Eastern Japan. And he teaches a course
on microeconomics--

The Microeconomics
of Competitiveness with Professor Michael Porter.

He's no stranger to the
best-dressed faculty list.

He's a much-loved member
of the HBS community. And it's no wonder that he
suggested we keep this time

slot in the afternoon
for our convenience, even though it is 4:30
on Wednesday morning

for him in Tokyo. So Hiro, thank you
again for being with us. Perhaps before we [AUDIO OUT]
a little peek into what's

life like in Tokyo? Over to you. HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: Oh, life
in Tokyo is not so bad.

I've been here since January 1. I taught the immersive
field course here in Tokyo.

And I've been here
since, because of a lot of the
restrictions for travel.

I was supposed to be in Maui
this week, but that's gone. So it's not bad.
It's self-restraint. So I can still walk around.

I can still go to places. But it is restrictive. But this is the
world we live in now.

DEB WALLACE: Yeah, right. HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: So am
I on the screen right now?

DEB WALLACE: [AUDIO OUT]. Moriah is going to share
your slides right now. HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: OK. So let's go with the slides.

I'll do a little self
introduction using the slides if that's OK.

OK. So that's the first slide. That's the title of
the presentation today.

Let me go to the second slide-- the first slide-- which is me
back in those days teaching
marketing. So next slide, please. Yeah. Oh, you went too far.
Let's back up. No, back up. Yep. There I am-- 1976 to '83.

This is teaching section
[? GNH ?] the first year in 1976.

So I was 29 years
old then, and got
this fever of the case method. So I'm teaching marketing there.

I used to have an
office in Gallatin, and very fortunate that
my neighbor in Gallatin

was Mike Porter. And we shared a secretary for
seven years, from '76 to '83.

And let me call you, that's
called strategic positioning. For me, that was
very, very helpful

to be with him at that time. And then I moved to Tokyo-- next slide-- and I worked with
Jiro Nonaka, who's on your left

here. And we've been kind of working
on the knowledge management

stuff. I ended up being the founding
dean of the business school

at Hitotsubashi, where
Jiro and I used to work.

I did come to Harvard
to teach as a visiting
professor in the AMP program. But I was there until 2010.

In 2010-- next slide-- I came back to the
Harvard Business School
as a professor of management. And I've been here since.

I was supposed to
retire this year, 2020, but Nitin basically said, hey,
you don't have a successor.

You've got to wait
until your successor is ready to take on your job
as faculty chair for Japan.

So Mike was the one
who brought me back to the Harvard Business School.

And as Deb mentioned, I used
to teach MOC, Microeconomics of Competitiveness, and
also taught a course

on knowledge-based strategy. But the signature
course for me is

what used to be called IXP,
Immersive Experience Program, now called IFC.

So I take about 45 students
to Tohoku, to Japan.

And the theme the
last three years has been the fusion
of digital and analog.

Until then, it was about
Tohoku, the earthquake tsunami.

I'll talk a little
bit about that later. So let me turn to the
research I've been doing.

Next slide. The book that Jiro and I
have written 24 years ago

is called The
Knowledge-Creating Company. So both Jiro and I
graduated from UC Berkeley--

MBA and PhD. So back then our research
was on data analysis.

We did quite a bit of that. And then we moved on to
information processing.

Herbert Simon had an impact
on us, so we did a lot of work on information processing.

And then we went from data
to information to knowledge.

And this is a book we wrote 24
years ago, with a lot of cases

from Japanese companies. So the subtitle is, How
Japanese Companies Create the Dynamics of Innovation.

So the key thing about
this book-- next slide-- is the fact that we humans
have both explicit knowledge

and tacit knowledge, and
we focused on the latter, the tacit knowledge.

Explicit knowledge is
the tip of the iceberg. Tacit knowledge
resides underwater.

We got plenty of that. And the theory that
we presented is

called the SECI model, which
is the next slide, which is converting tacit to
explicit, explicit to tacit.

So new knowledge is
created if you convert one type of knowledge to the other.

And also, new
knowledge is created by going from the individual
to organizational knowledge

creation. So knowledge resides
in us, in humans.

Peter Drucker said it best. He says, it's the head and
hand of every individual.

The head is the explicit
knowledge, which is digital. And the hand is the experience,
which is the analog part.

So converting two types of
knowledge into each other creates new knowledge.

That was the theory. The new book, which
is the next slide,

we now move from
knowledge to wisdom. So now the new book is
called The Wise Company.

It took us 24 years
to write this book. And what is wisdom?

All you have to think
about is mother's wisdom. So all of you have learned
from your mother's wisdom.

She probably said things
ceaselessly, repeatedly. It's probably embedded in you.

And the whole thesis
of the new book is knowledge is of no
value unless you put it

into practice. So we've gone from knowledge
creation to knowledge practice,

and that's the gist
of the new book. And, the next slide, we
borrowed from Aristotle.

So it took us 24
years, but we borrowed from Aristotle who lived 2,400
years ago, so 100 times more

than from the last book. And here are the
three virtues that he

talked about 2,400 years ago. We use the first two quite a bit
in management-- epistemology,

technology. But the third one he postulated
back then was phronesis.

And our shorthand definition
is know what should be done.

So there's action,
there's practice involved. And so we kind of
use that, phronesis,

which in English is kind of
known as practical wisdom

to create a revised model,
which is the next slide.

And as you can see, it has
become three-dimensional. It has become dynamic.

We have SECI, the S-E-C-I model,
which is kind of the knowledge

spiraling up from individual to
organization up to the society

level. So here, is it possible to
convert back to me, Deborah?

And I'd like to do an exercise
with the hundreds of you, or maybe a little bit more,
on what a spiral really means.

And what I'd like you to do
is kind of point your finger
up towards the ceiling-- around your belly would be best.

And if you could kind of
with the finger pointing up create a little circle.

Important thing is turn
the circle clockwise. Can you do that, everybody--

a little circle around your
belly right with your finger pointing up?

And then bring it up
to your chest level, with the circle a little larger.

Bring it with still your finger
pointing up shoulder level,

eye level. Make the circle a little
bigger, and up above your head.
And now look at the circle. It's turning clockwise, correct?

DEB WALLACE: Yeah. HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: No. It's turning the other
way around, correct? So something
happened dynamically,

where it was turning clockwise,
and all of a sudden you see it going the
other way around. Now, in order to kind of
understand the logic of that,

you have to buy the
book and read it. So let me turn
back to the slide. But there's something
mysterious about the spiral.

So going back to
the spiral, this is the new model that we
created in the new book.

I won't go through this
because it'll take me about an hour to explain this. But two important things--

the time dimension is
right in the middle. So we are now created a
dynamic model rather than

a static model. And now it's the
ontological level

has gone from the individual,
up to the organization, to the society. And I'll talk a
little bit about that.

So from a strategy
point of view-- next slide, please--
it now becomes

kind of important to talk
about the mission, vision, values, which basically
comes from what

we call an inside-out
approach to strategy. You start with the
beliefs, the ideals

of the founder or the manager. And you talk about the vision,
which is what kind of a future

do I want to create? And you have your important
values, your beliefs

that support your strategy. I'll come back to
this a little bit. But humans are at the
center of knowledge creation

and knowledge practice,
especially knowledge practice. And we also think
that the future

should be an important part-- future creation,
making the future. Peter Drucker said it best--

"You cannot predict the future,
but you can make the future,"

he said 50 years ago. And so we kind of
follow that logic

of trying to make
future a stakeholder, in addition to shareholder.

And let me end
with a case that we use at the start of the book.

The next slide shows
Soichiro Honda. And I don't know if
you use the Honda

case, for those of
you who are MBAs, in the strat first-year course.

But we talk about why
Honda became so successful

in motorcycles in the US. So there was Honda A and a Honda
B, if you recall that case.

And this is Honda
back in those days when he was making motorcycles.

But did you know
that on the side of every Super Cub,
the motorcycle,

that any motorcycle
that Honda makes is a logo, which is the
next slide, of a wing.

So Honda, from his early
days, childhood days,

always wanted to fly. That was his passion. He got a-- became
a licensed pilot.

His wife also became a pilot. He wanted to fly. And so human mobility
was his thing,

but it went from bicycles
to motorcycles to cars,

and eventually--
the next slide--  Honda Jet.

So this was created,
developed, took him 29 years.

Of course, he passed away before
the Honda Jet was created. But this is the best-selling
small jet in the United States

right now. This is three years
after it was developed. And this kind of shows
that it was Honda's dream

to come up with a jet. And he always had the wing
on all the motorcycles.

And it took a young Honda
employee by the name of Fujino

to make this a reality. And this was
developed in the US.

And while Honda Soichiro's
dream was to fly this himself,

Fujino's vision-- what kind of a future
do I want to create--

was he basically, when
we interviewed him said, I want to make the life of
American executives better.

Instead of waiting
at airports, instead of waiting for
the plane to come,

why not create an affordable-- this cost $4.8 million, so
he calls it affordable--

jet like this, which
is fuel-efficient. He basically said, it's
a combination of a Civic

and an NSX, which
is their sports car. It's sexy, and it's
the best-selling jet
in the United States right now. So let me stop there. If you can swing back to me.
Are you still doing this or not?

So that's kind of the
part of my lecture. Let me stop there for
a sec and maybe talk

a little about the extension of
what I'm doing with the book.

I am now, because of coronavirus
and being kind of pegged

in my home, writing an article
for the Harvard Business Review. It's called
"Humanizing Strategy."

So I don't know how
many of you have gone through the first-year
MBA course on strategy here.

We still teach it in
an outside-in approach, which is analyze
the environment,

analyze your competitor,
but before that, analyze the industry. Remember five forces?

Analyze the industry,
analyze your competitor, and decide on your
strategic positioning
based on those analyses. So it's outside-in.

And what we're saying
in the new article is, well, strategy should
also be inside-out.

Start from your beliefs,
start from your ideals, and then try to
create a future that

is better than what it is now. And make sure that
you're not only

benefiting your shareholder,
but society at large. So maximizing shareholder value
is what strategy is all about.

We talk about SSP-- Superior Sustainable
Profitability.

Yes, that's all good. But in the new book, we're
talking about the importance

of common good for society. So we're trying to write
a new article, which is

called "Humanizing Strategy." And we put a lot of evidence
from neuroscience into it.

Because the brain,
we're finding out, works quite a bit in favor
of what we're saying.

It kind of-- it has
an uncanny ability to deal with complexity.

It always is changing. It's very good about thinking,
imagining the future.

So there's a lot of support
coming from neuroscience

into what we're doing. And we're putting humans
at the center of strategy.

So when we talk about, what's
the origin of strategy?

How do firms differ? In first-year strategy
we said, firms

differ because they have
a different value chain. So that was kind of the answer. We basically say, no,
firms differ because they
envision different futures. So humans can imagine.

We can deal with complexity. We can sniff the wind. So that's kind of the
basis of our new article.

But it's based on recent
findings in neuroscience.

So look forward to that
in six months or so. And we've also written
an article on innovation.

And we kind of split
innovation into three stages. The first stage being 0 to 1,
the second stage being 1 to 9,

and the third stage
being 9 to 10. And we kind of agree, most
of the innovation, 1 to 9,

is going to come through
digital transformation. It's going to be the
artificial intelligence.
It's going to be IoT. It's also going to be AR.

So all the things-- the data analytics, the
blockchain-- all these things

are going to create lots
of innovation, 1 to 9.

But from 0 to 1 and 9 to
10 is where humans excel.

Because in the 0 to 1 stage
you have to have imagination.
You have to have intuition. You have to have some gut feel. That's how new ideas come.

And we still think
that humans are better than machines in that area.

In 9 to 10 it's more the
sensitivity that humans have.

It's kind of the analog thing
that's good with humans.
We have a good example of that.

Let me use another
Honda example, is ASIMO.

So they created this thing,
a human robot, 25 years ago.

The mission back then was to be
able to beat the winning soccer

team in 2050 in soccer
with 11 ASIMO robots

playing against
Barcelona or whoever. So that was the mission.

But four years ago
they said, no, we're going to change the mission.

They made the robot shorter. It's now 163 centimeters,
which is like 5 feet 7.

They made the fingers much more
nimble, rather than the feet. It runs around 10 miles
per hour right now.
It can jump. It can do all kinds of things. But now it's more the fingers. Why?

Because they want the
robots to help the elderly-- we take baths in Japan--

so put them into the bath,
take them out of the bath. So help them at home
mostly for the elderly.

So they changed the vision-- what kind of a future
do we want to create-- into a society that would
be kind to the elders.

So that's the kind of thing that
I think humans can think about.

So it's actually
the 9 to 10 part is the sensitivity part
of understanding what's

important in the
world right now. Let me stop there. I've talked for 24
minutes straight.

And you probably have
questions to ask. And so at this
point in time, I'm

going to try to sip my
first coffee of the morning. And maybe, Deb, you want
to start with a question?

DEB WALLACE: Sure. I'll jump in. I'm amazed that you waited that
long for your coffee, Hiro. That's incredible.

So anybody in the audience, if
you want to type in a question,

we're fielding
those in a minute. But why don't we start with--

I'd like to pick up on the
IXP that you lead to Japan. So you've been studying those
long-term effects of crisis

management following the
earthquake and tsunami that devastated the Honshu region.

I think there were-- is it 9-- it's a
9.0 on the Richter.

There were over 16,000 deaths. There were hundreds of thousands
of people who were displaced,

and hundreds of thousands of
buildings that were damaged, including the Fukushima
nuclear power facility, which

was added to the devastation. So what can organizations today
learn from that experience,

apply to our current
pandemic challenges? What kind of wisdom could be
imparted from that experience?

HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: OK. Yeah. So I've been taking
students to Tohoku--

HBS students-- nine
years in a row. So next year it's in the J term.

So I take them in the
first two weeks in January. So next year it's going to
be our 10th anniversary.

So the people in Tohoku are just
absolutely amazed that 45 of us

will come every year, 10 years
in a row, 7,000 miles away,

to kind of help the
community there. What the students do is
work with organizations

in the Tohoku area to
restore the economy, to restore their business.

And we've been doing that
for the last nine years. And next year is going to
be a tenth anniversary.

And so I think the
same kind of philosophy

holds that we have in the book-- the importance of
the common good.

What can we do for
the common good? And in order to do that, we have
to make here and now decisions.

And so the students
kind of work with different social entrepreneurs,
different organizations,

different companies,
to try to help them to deal with
the complexity,

to deal with the disaster,
to deal with the uncertainty, and to rebuild the business.

So the same kind of mindset, I
think, can apply to the world
right now-- COVID-19. Because think of it.

We call it COVID-19 because
it happened in 2019.

But in 2019, who could have
predicted that a pandemic like

this would disrupt our
entire life like this?

No one would have predicted. So go back to what
Peter Drucker said.

"You cannot predict the future,
but you can make the future."

So I think it's the making the
future part that's important.

And I think what we need to
do is on a worldwide basis

have everybody
make a human chain,

cooperate, and see what we
can do for the common good. So there's, I think,
a very strong lesson

that we can learn. And one of the
reasons we're doing OK adapting to
coronavirus is Japan

is used to having
crises like this. So it was 2011, we
had the tsunami.

Last year we had the
typhoon devastate part

of places very close to Tokyo. So every 5, 10 years, we kind of
deal with these kind of crises.

And so when you ask the
mission of a company,

most CEOs in Japan-- we'll say, what's your mission? They do not say maximize
shareholder value.

In Japanese they
will say, [JAPANESE].. And it literally translates
to, for the good of society,
for the good of humans. [JAPANESE] So why do we exist?

We exist for that. So the mission is very clear. And the vision is, what kind of
a future do we want to create?

So they're constantly
talking long term. So it took Honda 29 years
to develop the Honda Jet.

So longevity, survival for
the Japanese companies, that's

kind of the goal. The goal post is not to sell out
and maximize shareholder value.

It's to create a better life. It's create a better society. So I think there's kind of a
very strong link to the fact

that we had that
crisis with 3/11.

And now we're kind of
better able to adapt. And that's what
humans are good at.

We have the uncanny ability
to adapt, to change.

Let me stop there.  DEB WALLACE: We have another
question about Uniqlo,

and I know you've been
involved with them. Where do you see them fitting
in the wisdom creation cycle?

HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: Uniqlo
is an upcoming firm.
He has been CEO for 40 years.

He's trying to pass the
baton to the next generation. But Uniqlo, I think, is
seen more in the league

of [JAPANESE] companies. Because for one thing, the
reason I was with him is he

created a scholarship
for high school students

in Japan who gets accepted
to American universities--

liberal arts colleges. And he designated about 35 of
them, and Harvard is included.

And so is UC Berkeley,
my alma mater. But it doesn't have to be the
big ones, the famous ones.

Small liberal arts
universities are fine. So for the last four
years, on average he's

given out 30 scholarships
to 30 students, and each scholarship is $70,000
a year times four, so $280,000.

And he, like me, don't believe
in the higher education

system in Japan. He is a graduate of
Waseda University, which is a good university.

But he thinks it's a lot
better for youngsters in Japan to go to study in
the United States.

And he added the UK
starting last year. And so he's seeing
the future of Japan

and saying the future
kind of belong to-- basically, he says to two
types of people, youngsters

and women. And so he says, I'm going to put
my money to these individuals.

And that's kind of
the mindset he has. So with the current business,
with the current crisis,

his sales are down by 30%. All the stores in
Southeast Asia are closed.

All the stores in the
United States and in Europe

are closed. But he says, we can survive. We can still be giving
out used clothes

to refugees for the
next three years. And it's that kind of mindset
that is respected here,

thinking about the
common good, and making here and now decisions. So I did write about
Mr. Yanai and Uniqlo

in the Tohoku case
series that I had.

And what was very interesting
is the students actually wrote the case.

And my name is on it
because you need a Harvard faculty to issue a case. But second line of
the case, it says

Mr. Yanai was eating
sushi on the day of the earthquake at 5:30 PM.
The earthquake hit at 2:46 PM. Tsunami came 30 minutes later.

But the case wrote,
he was eating sushi at his favorite sushi
restaurant in Tokyo.

And he basically says, I was
able to do it because he has--

the store managers
are in charge. And he has trained all the
store managers to think like me.

So leave it up to them. We can be on autopilot and
they'll do the right thing.

So that kind of-- what was interesting
is the legal department wanted me to erase
that line because it

could be misinterpreted. But he says, hey,
what's wrong with that? That's reality, so put it in.

But we did erase the
third line which says,

the earthquake hit on a Friday. But he says, Mr. Yanai went
to his favorite golf course

the next morning,
but nobody was there. We deleted that,
because that we thought may be a little controversial.

So let me stop there. DEB WALLACE: Yeah. Yeah. So Hiro, we've got a
couple of questions

around maximizing
shareholder value. John [INAUDIBLE],,
one of our alums,

he writes, you
referenced Herbert Simon. Any thoughts on his concept
of satisficing 20-plus years

before Michael Jensen's
maximizing shareholder value? And then added to that is,
what's the conversation at HBS

around maximizing-- shifting away from
maximizing shareholder value?

HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: Yeah, quite a
bit of shift since [AUDIO OUT]..

We don't deny that should
be one of the goals. Because one of the stakeholders
is the shareholder for sure.

But let's don't forget employees
are also a stakeholder,

customers, society at large. And we, in our new article,
say the future is also

a stakeholder. So we have no
problem with having--

maximizing shareholder
value as satisfying one of the stakeholders.

But we also have to kind of
satisfy other stakeholders.

And I think the Business
Roundtable issued a statement--

was it August-- saying
shareholder is not everything.

So there were 181 CEOs
of companies like Amazon,

like Apple, who signed
the declaration. So there is kind of a movement
and saying, let's not only talk

about maximizing
shareholder value. Nitin, clearly by coming
out with the statement

from knowing to doing to being,
he kind of made a big shift

in thinking about, what's
the mission of companies?

I mean, the mission of HBS
students is very clear-- make a difference in the world.

So we're educating
students who would make a difference in the world. And I think what I'm
seeing is a lot of students

now are going to work for
companies that only employ one

Harvard MBA. And those are mostly
start-up companies. And many of them are
social entrepreneurs.

So we've kind of shifted from-- in early days when I
first taught, '76 to '83,

the students were trying
to work for large companies But now 70% of our
students are getting

employed by companies that
only employ one Harvard MBA.

So these are the
changing times I think. And Herbert Simon--
hallelujah to him.

He's sort of the one who talked
about the bounded rationality.

And he created a
computer model where

he saw the company as an
information processing machine. And his thoughts, I think,
are still dear to us.

Well, let me stop there. DEB WALLACE: There's another
question from Ron Chandler,
who's the CIO at HBS. And he says-- you know Ron.

Yeah. So he says, thank you for
spending time with us. I'm sure you're familiar
with Peter Senge's work

and the learning organization. He speaks of the importance
of personal mastery and mental

models among other things. How do you reconcile
the hero mindset--

that's H-E-R-O mindset--
versus high-performing teams to achieve overall
organizational success?

HIROTAKA TAKEUCHI: Yeah. We did quote Peter
Senge quite a bit in the first book 24 years ago.

So our thinking with the
five principles, very similar

in our thinking. But I think our thinking is
much, much more idealistic

in a sense. We kind of put humans at
the center of our thinking.

And humans are not
that mechanical,

in a sense, where we do have
the analytical capabilities,

but we're kind of
subjective creatures. We imagine things.

So I think in terms
of the new book,

we put quite a bit of
emphasis on being agile.

We use the Scrum approach
that Jeff Sutherland has come up with.

In fact, Jeff Sutherland calls
us the grandfather of agile.

And we asked him,
why grandfather? We're younger than you, Jeff.

But his response was, I'm the
father of the agile movement, but I learned a metaphor
from your 1986 article

in the Harvard Business
Review on the new new product development. And he says, I learned
